title: 105_hr2376
content: The Act may be cited as the National Fish and Wildlife Foundation Establishment Act Amendments of 1998. Any reference to an amendment or repeal in this Act is considered to be made to the National Fish and Wildlife Foundation Establishment Act. Membership of the Board of Directors of the Foundation is addressed in Section 2. Amendments to Section 3 of the National Fish and Wildlife Foundation Establishment Act include increasing the number of members from 15 to 22, reducing the required expertise from six to four members, and specifying that four members must be knowledgeable in ocean and coastal resource conservation. The Under Secretary of Commerce for Oceans and Atmosphere is also included as a member of the Board of Directors. The Secretary of the Interior appoints Directors of the Board for 6-year terms, with initial appointments staggered at 2, 4, and 6 years. No individual can serve more than 2 consecutive terms. The Board of Directors of the National Fish and Wildlife Foundation appoints Directors for 6-year terms, with initial appointments staggered at 2, 4, and 6 years. Vacancies must be filled within 60 days, and appointees serve the remainder of the term. The Board can recommend individuals for appointment as Directors. These amendments apply to appointments made after the enactment of this Act. Additional members can be nominated for positions on the Board. The Board of Directors of the National Fish and Wildlife Foundation appoints individuals to staggered terms, with appointments made within 60 days of enactment. Terms expire in 1999, 2001, and 2003 as specified by the Secretary of the Interior. The National Fish and Wildlife Foundation's rights and obligations are outlined in Section 3. The National Fish and Wildlife Foundation can invest and deposit federal funds in obligations or securities guaranteed by the United States, use interest income for Foundation purposes, and provide federal funds for specific purposes. The National Fish and Wildlife Foundation can use federal funds to enter cooperative agreements with private landowners for restoration of natural resources and accept funds from other federal agencies. The National Fish and Wildlife Foundation can use federal funds for restoration projects with private landowners. Section 304 of Public Law 102-440 is repealed, and agency approval is required for conveyances or grants involving federal funds. The National Fish and Wildlife Foundation can convey real property acquired with federal funds if the property is no longer valuable for conservation purposes and the Foundation's activities would benefit from the proceeds. Agency approval is required within 60 days if there is disagreement. The National Fish and Wildlife Foundation can convey real property acquired with federal funds if it is no longer valuable for conservation purposes and the Foundation's activities would benefit from the proceeds. Section 4(d) is amended to limit expenditures for printing or capital equipment to $10,000 without approval from the administering Federal agency. SEC. 4. Matching requirement amended to "matching, on a one-to-one basis." SEC. 5. Restrictions on use of grants provided by Foundation. Section 10(b) (16 U.S.C. 3709(b)) is amended to restrict the use of grants provided by the Foundation. Amounts cannot be used for litigation expenses or activities influencing legislation. However, officers or employees can communicate legislative requests related to the Foundation's business. Additionally, grants cannot be used for activities introducing wolves or grizzly bears in certain states. Authorization of appropriations is also mentioned. SEC. 6. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. Amends Section 10(a) to authorize $25,000,000 for fiscal year 1999 to the Secretary of the Interior and the Secretary of Commerce. Repeals Section 10(c).
